The areas that call for increased spending [by patients] and cut backs of services are women’s issues. They are going back to treating pregnancy as a pre-existing condition. I can’t tell you…before the [Affordable Care Act] how many people came to see me and couldn’t get health insurance because they were pregnant.

Yesterday I announced with Rep. Ed Royce that our bill to create a Smithsonian museum dedicated to American women’s history on the National Mall is now supported by a majority of the House of Representatives.   HR19, the Smithsonian Women's History Museum Act, was named for the 19th Amendment which enshrined a woman's right to vote in the US Constitution.

Alongside the observance of that great historical milestone of #July4th, the day when Declaration of Independence was signed in 1776, boldly proclaiming the revolutionary idea that all men are created equal, I think we should consider some kind of national observance on August 26th.   August 26, 1920 was the day when the other half of this great nation got the right to vote: the women.  On that day, the 19th Amendment, guaranteeing women the right to vote, was signed by the Secretary of State and thus became a part of the Constitution. It said:   "The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on account of sex...Congress shall have power to enforce this article by appropriate legislation."  But no one was there to see the signing. None of the leaders of the woman suffrage movement who had labored for years for its passage -  were present when the proclamation was signed, and no photographers or film cameras recorded the event.   I think some celebration is a bit overdue. What do you think?  Here’s a brief history.

The cold-blooded assassination of Officer Miosotis Familia, while she was sitting in a police vehicle in the Bronx early this morning, was a horrific and contemptible act of mindless savagery.  Officer Familia was only there to do what she had been doing every work day for the past 12 years: serve and protect the city she loved. My most heartfelt condolences go to her family, her friends and all of her colleagues who serve with her in the New York Police Department.   This heartbreaking tragedy is a reminder of the risks that the men and women of the NYPD face every day as they work to protect us. All of us owe a tremendous debt of gratitude for the service and sacrifices that the NYPD make on our behalf.
Great story in The New York Times about the effort to get every public school in the U.S. to teach coding.   I hope New York will consider this proposal! It's time we invest in #STEM education!

Our country’s rich history is filled with awe-inspiring stories and rich characters. Yet, too often when we tell these stories and celebrate our history, women are mere footnotes or simply left out altogether.

America has lost a great champion of women’s rights with Betty Dukes’ passing.  I was honored to meet her this past April at Hunter College to talk about the need to pass the #EqualRightsAmendment and her work highlighting gender discrimination in the workplace.    Ms. Dukes was the Wal-Mart greeter who brought a class action lawsuit when she realized that she and other women employed by Wal-Mart were facing systematic discrimination. They had evidence showing that women faced systematic discrimination in pay and opportunity, and that management relied on outdated stereotypes and assumptions about their female employees in making hiring and promotion decisions. The case went all the way to the Supreme Court where a sharply divided court ruled that there was not enough evidence of a common employment policy to certify all female employees of Walmart as a class.  In her dissent, Ruth Bader Ginsburg wrote: “The plaintiffs’ evidence, including class members’ tales of their own experiences, suggest that gender bias suffused Wal-Mart’s company culture.”  Sadly, the case helped underscore the need for an Equal Rights Amendment to address the gap in pay and opportunities women continue to face.    I welcomed Betty Dukes strong voice in the fight for the Equal Rights Amendment and I am so sorry that she is no longer with us as we continue the fight for an #ERAnow.

It’s a beautiful morning for a #groundbreaking! I’m proud that we have finally begun phase 1 of the #EastRiverEsplanade sea wall reconstruction. We’ve come a long way since I created the East River Esplanade Task Force in 2010.   We now have a study documenting the problems, a plan for fixing them, funding for phases I and II of the plan, contributions from The Rockefeller University and the Hospital for Special Surgery to fix portions of the Esplanade and a commitment that the City will provide more funding to complete the work.  The waterfront Greenway along the East River is a gem, and is one of the most breathtaking spots in our city. I am thrilled that the Mayor and my colleagues in government have been so generous and committed to the effort to repair and improve the East River Esplanade.

Joined Al Gore for a screening of An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power. He is a great voice in the fight against climate change and I am proud to stand with him and #LeadOnClimate because the threat is real. Remember to #BeInconvenient!

The CDC reports that more than 500,000 women and girls in the US have suffered or are at risk for female genital mutilation. My & Congressman Dave Trott's Stopping Abusive Female Exploitation (SAFE) Act aims to stop it.
Just one hour until I'm on #Periscope with the amazing Peter Morley to discuss healthcare. Hope you'll tune in!

ICYMI: Friday afternoon I sat down to discuss #healthcare with NY12 constituent, and patient advocate, Peter Morley.   If the #ACA is repealed, 32 million more Americans like Peter will lose their coverage. We cannot allow that to happen.
This is why I fight for the #ACA and to #ProtectOurCare. Thank you to everyone who has shared their story.
To strip people of the healthcare they need to survive would be as immoral as any act ever perpetrated under the guise of governance. We must #ProtectOurCare.

I continue to fight #ACARepeal because of people like Peter Morley, Baby Theo & twitter user RedTRaccoon. We must #ProtectOurCare.  Each of them – and millions more – will suffer if repeal or replace goes forward. I believe we are a greater, more caring nation than this.  I believe we can, we shall, we must do better.

While the Senate GOP was voting to take away health care, the House GOP was voting to take away consumer protections.  I spoke out against this becuase we should always put #ConsumersFirst. I'll continue to #DefendCFPB.

The Senate Republicans may have passed an #ACARepeal motion to proceed, but this isn't over by a long shot. Americans still have a voice & so do I.   #Healthcare advocates all across this country give me hope. Please keep sharing your stories. Together we can defeat this bill and #ProtectOurCare.

I stand proudly with the transgender community and am a proud member of the Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus.   President Trump’s announcement that he will ban transgender individuals from serving in our armed services is blatant discrimination and completely un-American. It’s hard to overstate the irony that he chose to make this announcement during the White House’s American Heroes Week. With this announcement he has disrespected countless veterans and current service members.

ICYMI: While Senate Republicans are working to rip #healthcare away from millions of Americans, I spoke with Peter Morley, a constituent and patient advocate, about how repeal would put his and others' lives in danger.

Thank you to the millions of advocates, like Peter Morley and “Red Raccoon,” who made sure we knew your #healthcare stories. You made this happen.  And thank you to the U.S. Senate Democrats for their nonstop work and Senators McCain, Murkowski and Collins for your brave votes to protect healthcare for millions.   It’s time now for Democrats and Republicans to work together to strengthen the #AffordableCareAct by bringing down costs and doing more to expand access.

Today in #HerStory, Alice Huyler Ramsey completed her historic journey across the country to become the first woman to drive across the United States. Driving from Manhattan to San Francisco, a 22-year-old Ramsey completed the trip on August 7, 1909. In a time when women were not encouraged to drive cars, Ramsey defied stereotypes and traveled 3,600 miles with three other women. The journey was not an easy one, but she overcame obstacles along the way to successfully drive coast to coast, and later went on to be the first woman to be inducted into the Automotive Hall of Fame. Today we remember Alice Ramsey and her remarkable journey that earned her a place in #HerStory. http://www.smithsonianmag.com/history/alice-ramseys-historic-cross-country-drive-29114570/

This public-private partnership creates jobs for New Yorkers and establishes #LGA as a key driver of economic growth. As tensions escalate with North Korea, we must remind ourselves that military action, and risking American soldiers' lives, should never be the first response. It should be a last resort, and we are far from exhausting all available diplomatic options.   Secretary of Defense General James Mattis served more than four decades in the Marine Corps and is known as one of the most influential military leaders of his generation. He has told us that diplomatic efforts to contain the threat posed by North Korea are working, and should remain the favored means for solving the crisis.   I agree we should explore all diplomatic options before taking military action.
I am shocked and outraged by the violence and bigotry of the KKK-aligned protestors in Charlottesville today. Their hatred has no place in our country.

The President’s assertion that helmeted neo-Nazis carrying flags with Swastikas, chanting anti-Semitic slogans along with White Supremacists calling for racial purity are somehow morally equivalent to people protesting such hateful behavior is profoundly disturbing.  No condemnation of Nazis and the anti-Semitism they espouse should end with: "but…."  No denunciation of White Supremacists and the racial bigotry they embrace should end with: "on the other hand…."  These hate groups and individuals espouse the worst kind of hatred, bigotry, anti-Semitism. They descended on a quiet college town, hoping for a confrontation. Some of them came armed with assault rifles, brandishing clubs and shields, and waving Nazi flags. Many came wearing helmets, body armor, and military clothing. The violence they sought and the violence they caused is flat out evil. Full stop. No one should suggest that they have the same moral standing as those who opposed them. I have been to Auschwitz in the company of Holocaust survivors.  I have seen where this kind of blind unreasoning hatred can lead if people do not speak out loudly, clearly, and forcefully.  Make no mistake, this weekend’s actions by members of the alt-Right and the KKK-aligned groups that marched in Charlottesville is not the end of this. The hatred that motivated them is still alive in our nation. I am deeply disappointed that our President has refused to clearly and plainly admit this fact. His failure to forcefully condemn these groups is a failure of great significance. It’s also long past time for the President to fire Steve Bannon, who should never have been hired in the first place. We must do better than this as a nation. We must not be silent. In matters as important as this, silence equals consent.
Proud to cosponsor this resolution. Those supporting White Supremacists do not belong in The White House.

In light of North Korea’s provocative actions to advance its nuclear capability and escalating tensions, it is important to reaffirm our alliances with Japan, South Korea, and China.   I am currently on a Congressional Delegation trip to these countries to visit with our allies in Asia to help strengthen all diplomatic lines of communication to resolve any issues affecting security in the region.

I’m proud to cosponsor the House measure to censure the President’s failure to forcefully condemn #Charlottesville hate groups and white supremacists.   I hope that my all my colleagues in the House, Democrats and Republicans, will join us in making it clear that hatred and racism have no place in our country and certainly not in our White House.

My thoughts and prayers are with the people of Barcelona and all of Spain today. There is no excuse, no cause that warrants such an evil, hateful action and taking of innocent lives.  We stand with Spain, and our allies around the world, against terror. We will continue to work together to dismantle terrorist networks worldwide and defeat these threats to our nations, democracies, and values. Together, we will ensure that terror, hate, and fear cannot win.
Bannon, who gloated about providing a platform for the alt-right, never belonged in The White House.
97 years after the ratification of the #19thAmendment, women may have the right to vote but are still not guaranteed equality. We need #ERAnow.
Hoping for the safe return of the 10 missing U.S. Navy sailors & swift recoveries of those injured.
Couldn't agree more, The Femomist. It’s high time we “remember the ladies”—once and for all. #ERAnow
I stand with the Congressional Black Caucus and its efforts to #RootOutRacism in federal policy, The White House & on federal property.
The new memo from President Donald J. Trump outlining implementation of the military's ban on transgender individuals is an ugly example of blatant discrimination. #TransRightsAreHumanRights

Congresswoman Maloney and women leaders ring the opening bell at Nasdaq for Women's Equality Day  Kathy Hochul National Organization for Women (NOW) National Women's Political Caucus National Women's History Museum New York Life Insurance Company Girl Scouts of Greater New York Marie Claire Manhattan Chamber of Commerce DailyClout New York Junior League Junior League Upper East Side for Change Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America ERA Coalition Carol Jenkins Maya Wiley Women's eNews The Estée Lauder Companies

Had a wonderful time this morning ringing the opening bell at Nasdaq in recognition of #WomensEqualityDay and a need for an Equal Rights Amendment and a Smithsonian Women’s History Museum to tell #HERstory. While we commemorate the certification of the 19th Amendment and celebrate the progress we have made towards equality, we are also reminded that women do not still have full equality under the law. It is up to us to follow in the footsteps of the suffragists who came before and do our part to make our country a more perfect union.
Here's why we commemorate #WomensEqualityDay.
See my op-ed in the New York Daily News with Congressman Peter King about our bill to end secret shell companies that finance drugs, trafficking & terrorism.

I’m thrilled that the NYC Ferry Astoria Route is now officially opened. With stops in Astoria, Roosevelt Island, Long Island City,  East 34th Street, and Wall Street, this route will connect many different communities in our NY-12th Congressional District, and will be a boon to commuters, tourists, and New Yorkers trying to experience a new neighborhood. I’m proud to have worked with Mayor Bill de Blasio on this important addition to New York City.
Happy #womencrushwednesday to two women I admire who crush it every day, Lieutenant Governor Kathy Hochul and my daughter Virginia! #WCW
Workers’ rights & the freedom to choose if & when to start a family are central to women’s economic security. #NotWithoutRepro #LaborDay
#DREAMers are our neighbors, classmates, & colleagues. We will stand w you & #DefendDACA! Our diversity & immigrants make America great.
President Donald J. Trump's deliberate attempt to undermine the #ACA instead of helping people get the healthcare insurance they need is disgraceful.

Since 2012, when DACA was first launched, nearly 800,000 young people have been enrolled in the program. DACA helped breathe life into the American dream for a generation of people who came to the United States as children seeking a better future, just as earlier generations of Americans did so. These individuals are our neighbors and friends who have grown up here in the United States, who have done nothing wrong, and have only ever known the United States as their home. Before DACA, these young people had lived in the shadows of our communities. Since DACA began, these good-hearted Americans have come forward in hopes of being granted fully legal status and the chance to continue making positive contributions to their communities and our country without fear of deportation.   DACA participants bring real economic benefits to our states and nation. A recent Center for American Progress assessment found that ending the DACA program would remove at least $460.3 billion from the U.S. GDP, cumulatively over a decade.   I will continue to do all I can to protect DREAMers and reverse this decision as we continue to work toward real, comprehensive immigration reform. The BRIDGE Act and the American Hope Act are good places to start. House Republican leadership should allow votes on these important pieces of legislation. It is our diversity and opportunity that makes this country so great, and I hope all my colleagues will take that to heart.”

As someone who represents a district that was hit hard by Superstorm Sandy, I have a hard-earned appreciation and respect for what the survivors of #HurricaneHarvey have been going through up to now and of the daunting challenge they face in rebuilding and recovering. That is why I wholeheartedly support this aid package and am proud of the House for doing the right thing and voting for the emergency funding #Houston so desperately needs.  The enormity of the economic impact that this kind of mass trauma can have and the toll it can take on people’s lives is hard to overstate. I hope the Senate will follow suit and quickly take up this bill and vote for this aid package so that we can get the needed funds to Houston as soon as possible.

I am very pleased that the House included a 3-month extension of the National Flood Insurance Program, which is critically important not only for New Yorkers, but also for the victims of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma.   This 3-month extension will give Congress time to work on a long-term reauthorization of the NFIP that is bipartisan, comprehensive, and most importantly, keeps flood insurance affordable for homeowners. During this 3-month extension, I will continue to fight for reforms that make flood insurance more affordable in dense urban areas like New York City, and to ensure that homeowners receive the money they’re owed when their homes are flooded.
A wonderful morning joining my Congressional Youth Cabinet for its inaugural meeting. They are the future and their voices need to be heard.

Today, I joined with the NY fashion industry to save the Garment District. It would not be possible to replicate the Garment District ecosystem, a complex, market driven aggregation of small businesses that has grown organically over nearly a century. It is this balance of designers, manufacturers, and retail stores that is critical to the success of New York City’s fashion industry, and NYFW. We must preserve the Garment District to protect our status as the Fashion Capital of the world and ensure that these businesses, the tens of thousands of jobs they offer, and the billions in economic activity and tax revenue they create do not leave the city.

As I said this week on the floor, and will continue to say: I stand with dreamers and we need pass immigration reform that protects them. We need a vote on the legislation that will make DACA permanent so that those who have only ever known the US as their home can continue to live their American Dreams.

As we have done on every September 11 since 2001, today we come together to remember the lives taken in the most brutal attack on American soil and to honor and thank the first responders who risked, and gave, their lives serving on the front lines.   We are reminded that even in our darkest hours, there is light. That light shows up in neighbor helping neighbor, in strangers lending a helping hand, in the way our entire country came together to support one another in the wake of such a horrible day.   We all pledged to ‘Never Forget’ and I took that message to heart. There are thousands of men and women who have lost their lives since 9/11 or are suffering serious illnesses today from their exposure to Ground Zero. It is for these men and women that I, Reps. Jerrold Nadler and Peter King, along with hundreds of dedicated advocates and volunteers, worked to make sure Congress kept its word to those who were there for us on 9/11 by passing the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Reauthorization Act. With its passage in December 2015, no one suffering from a 9/11-related disease will ever have to worry about whether they will get the specialized health care they need. With more than a dozen people each week still being diagnosed with a 9/11-related cancer, that certainty is more important ever.  At a time when our nation feels more divided than ever, let us remember the power of what we can accomplish and the good we can do when we focus on our shared values rather than what drives us apart.

As the world faces multiple humanitarian crises around the world, few political actions have been as cruel and shortsighted as the Trump administration’s decision to cut off funding to the United Nations Population Fund, or UNFPA.

It was with great sadness that I learned today of the death of my friend and hero, Edith Windsor, who will be remembered by historians for her Supreme Court case that led to marriage equality becoming the law of the land. But "Edie" will be remembered by those of us  lucky enough to know her as a warm, energetic, and courageous activist for equal rights, who changed the world for the better for millions, by following her heart and using her head.  Edie was a math wiz, who studied applied math at Harvard and rose through the ranks at IBM to become a Senior Systems Programmer. In a time when it was not easy, she was a woman who had the courage to listen closely to the murmurs of her own heart. After a brief, failed conventional marriage, she moved to my great city of New York, where she knew she would have the freedom to, as she put it, "let myself be gay."  Years later, her court victory made it possible for millions of same-sex couples to be married, to visit their loved ones in hospitals, and to enjoy federal recognition for the first time and with it, the numerous federal benefits only available to spouses, like Social Security.  I so enjoyed seeing her at the Stonewall National Monument dedication last June 27, 2016. She was as always, joyful and vibrant, beautiful and caring. The battle for equal rights of our LGBT citizens, had in many ways, begun at Stonewall, led up to the Supreme Court with Edie’s case, and continues to this day.  I think Edie Windsor is best remembered as one of those fortunate souls who can leave this life, knowing with certainty, that her courage and her actions helped to bend the moral arc of this universe a few degrees closer towards justice. My sincere condolences to her wife, Judith Kasen-Windsor and all those who loved her.
A women's healthcare choices are between her and her doctor, not her employer. This amendment is shameful.

This is a great day for the City of New York. With Cornell Tech’s focus on educating and training the next generation of high-tech leaders and Roosevelt Island’s proximity to Manhattan and to industrial space in Western Queens, this new institution has the potential to change the educational and economic landscape of New York City.  I worked hard to ensure that Cornell Technion was selected when the City was considering locations for the new applied science campus. The community in both Manhattan and Queens were eager to welcome the new campus, and it is clear that Cornell Tech has exceeded everyone’s expectations. The entire Roosevelt Island community is enjoying the beautiful 120,000 square feet of landscaped open space, and our students are already benefitting from Cornell’s partnership with P.S./I.S. 217 on STEM programs. They have truly become a part of our community on Roosevelt Island.  Cornell Tech will help diversify our city’s economic base and bring jobs through new start-ups. Already, there have been 30 new companies created with nearly $20 million in angel funding and venture capital, employing over 100 people. As students are welcomed to the new campus, we know this is just the beginning – and that the future for this institution will be bright.

Today, I asked the CEOs of credit reporting agencies TransUnion and Experian about their security measures after hackers accessed the personal financial information of more than 140 million United States individuals stored by Equifax.
Now is the time to do something great we can all agree on: a major infrastructure bill with funding for Second Avenue Subway.

This latest missile test is more evidence that we need to exhaust all diplomatic options to stop North Korea's threats to peace and security, including severe sanctions. While I was pleased that the UN Security Council imposed further sanctions earlier this week, they did not go far enough. It is time to cut off oil to North Korea.  It is also critical for China and Russia to strictly enforce all international sanctions and if they do not, then we must take steps to sanction companies and individuals that violate UN or US restrictions on activities with the North Koreans, as we did recently. As we do this work, we must also work with our allies in the region to get North Korea to the negotiating table and do the hard, diplomatic work to reduce tensions and move towards a nuclear free Korean peninsula.

Human trafficking is happening here in the United States, and we have an obligation — to trafficking victims, survivors and their families — to combat this horrendous act and punish it as the criminal activity it is.

Always a great time marching with my constituents in the Steuben Parade! Events like this help us to hold onto traditions and keep them alive. Thanks to German-American Steuben Parade Committee of Greater New York for a great event!

The Graham-Cassidy healthcare bill is the GOPs last ditch effort in the Senate to repeal the Affordable Care Act. It is the latest version of Trumpcare and is still just as bad as earlier versions and, like its predecessors, endangers the care of millions of Americans. The fight to #ProtectOurCare isn’t over.
The Senate GOP's push for a vote on #GrahamCassidy without knowing its cost or how many would lose care is reckless. #ProtectOurCare

I wish all those celebrating #RoshHashanah a very Happy New Year, one filled with joy, meaning and surrounded by  loved ones. The Jewish High Holy Days are a time to reflect upon the past year and think about what lies ahead. It is an opportunity to think about how we can better ourselves, contribute to our communities and support those in need.   I’ve been deeply inspired recently by the outpouring of support for the victims of Hurricanes Harvey and Irma. It was Tikkun olam in action. We witnessed the human instinct to help repair the world with reflexive and selfless acts of courage, often on behalf of total strangers. Those acts will no doubt help impacted communities on their long road to recovery. I hope those wonderful deeds will inspire all of us to do our part to create to make Tikkun olam a part of everyday life and, as communities are being hit by the recent earthquake and Hurricane Maria, that we will continue to help those affected by natural disasters. #ShanaTovah and my best wishes for a happy and sweet 5778.

As the days pass we receive more and more evidence that the Republican #GrahamCassidy healthcare bill would be devastating for Americans. New York would be hit particularly hard, with 114,875 New Yorkers losing tax credits that help them afford health insurance. This is unacceptable, and we must do all we can to #ProtectOurCare

Tune in here tomorrow at 11am to join me,  Nydia Velazquez, Corey Johnson, Patient Advocate Peter Morely, and medical industry professionals as we rally against the disastrous #GrahamCassidy healthcare bill. We must #ProtectOurCare.

"This community center is a one-stop information center for everything pertaining to the Second Avenue Subway," said Rep. Carolyn Maloney, whose district covers parts of Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.
I'm at city hall to rally against the disastrous #GrahamCassidy bill!

The situation on the Korean peninsula is one of the gravest threats facing the global community today, which is why I worked with Rep. Ann Wagner to host a bipartisan round table discussion with Korean Foreign Minister Kang Kyung-wha today.   Foreign Minister Kang and all of the members at our meeting emphasized the importance of the U.S. – South Korean alliance and the deep ties between our two countries. Now more than ever, it is critical for us to work with our allies to exhaust every diplomatic avenue possible to resolve the current crisis with North Korea. Diplomacy is the only viable means to addressing the current threats posed by North Korea and the world is fortunate to have a leader like Foreign Minister Kang at the negotiating table.

Overdraft fees hit the consumers who can afford them the least –cash-strapped hardworking Americans who are struggling to pay their bills.  These fees are unfair, deceptive, and outrageously high. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) found that by overdrafting their account, the average consumer pays a 17,000 percent interest rate. This is why I am not only working to pass my Overdraft Protection Act but am also calling on CFPB Director Cordray to act on this before his term ends.   Under my bill, overdraft fees will be required to be "reasonable and proportional" to the amount of the overdraft because a cup of coffee shouldn’t cost you $35. These abusive practices have been going on for far too long already, and it’s time that we crack down on them.
Wishing all those observing Yom Kippur an easy and meaningful fast. G'mar Hatima Tova.

The federal government’s response to the humanitarian crises in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands has been wholly inadequate.   Millions of Americans are starved for even the most basic of resources – food, water, medical care – because of the destruction from Hurricane Maria. It is critical that military assets and the Army Corps of Engineers, along with additional FEMA personnel, be deployed immediately to ensure relief supplies are delivered and basic services are restored. While that happens, the House and Senate need to pass legislation as quickly as possible to supplement those efforts. The people of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands should not be waiting for more than week to get the help they so desperately need.   Let’s act – now.

“I was proud to sign (the) discharge petition to force a floor vote on the bipartisan Dream Act, which would protect young Dreamers once and for all by allowing them to study, work and live in this country without fear of deportation,” Maloney said. “Dreamers know no home but the United States. They are our neighbors, our friends, our children’s classmates. These young people are an essential part of building this country’s future and I hope all my colleagues will take that to heart and support the Dream Act.”
Had a wonderful morning kicking off #PolishHeritageMonth at the 80th annual #PulaskiDayParade! We march to honor General Casimor Pulaski and Tadeusz Kosciuszko.

Once again today, we are mourning the loss of dozens of innocent lives and the injury of dozens more, all victims of another madman with a gun.    As we wait for answers as to how this happened and what the shooter’s motivations were, one thing is clear: enough is enough. It is time for Congress to act. It is time for us to stop just sending our "thoughts and prayers" and time for us to get serious about gun safety.   When it comes to our annual bloody toll from gun violence, America is shamefully unique among the economically advanced nations of the world. Congress’s chief responsibility is to keep Americans safe. On that, Congress is failing. Congress need to act.   My heart breaks for the victims, their loved ones and all those injured last night. I call on my colleagues to show that they care by doing something to prevent the next senseless tragedy.
It is appropriate to express our “thoughts and prayers” whenever a tragedy like this happens, but it is not enough. Without action to prevent the next massacre, these words ring hollow.

Today, I spoke on the House floor for April.   Her story is about one of the most complex and painful decisions a woman can face but, it would have been even more excruciating if this 20-week abortion ban we are debating was the law at the time.  18 weeks into her pregnancy, April and her husband discovered their baby had a birth defect - a lethal skeletal dysplasia.  Their baby would never be able to breathe on his own.  April was told that if the baby didn’t die in utero – he would surely die shortly after birth from slow suffocation.  April was heartbroken and she desperately hoped the news wasn’t true - so she asked for more tests.Those tests took an additional two weeks. Tragically, the tests confirmed the diagnosis.  So, at 21 weeks, April had an abortion.   With this bill, the federal government would compel every woman like April, against their will, to carry to term a fetus they knew would either be still-born or would suffer needlessly and die at birth.  On behalf of April, I urged my colleagues to vote no on H.R. 36. We must stop assaults on women’s health.
Proud to stand with House Democrats to #EndGunViolence. Majority of Americans support common sense #gunsafety reforms. We must act now.

"I am horrified that we even need to be having this conversation, that a sexual partner would violate their partner’s trust and consent like this. Stealthing is sexual assault,” said Rep. Maloney. “We need a hearing so that Congress can hear from the experts about how to best address this issue as we continue to amend our country’s and universities’ responses to sexual assault and rape.”

Ultimately, a national budget is like a deal between the American taxpayer and Congress. It is about how this country will spend their money. The GOP budget we’re debating today would stack the deck against working families. Anyone who looks at the fine print in this budget plan  can tell you at a glance that the American people want, need and deserve #ABetterDeal.

I loved talking to some of our DREAMers last night. If your status expires before 3/5/2018, today is the last day to reregister for #DACA. Spread the word!   https://www.uscis.gov/humanitarian/consideration-deferred-action-childhood-arrivals-process/renew-your-daca
Mayor de Blasio has committed $100 million to expanding the East River Esplanade from 61st to 53rd streets. Midtown desperately needs more open space and this beautiful new greenway helps provide it.
At yesterday’s House Financial Services hearing I told former Equifax CEO Smith that his company violated the law & owes the American people answers.

Birth control is healthcare. Women need it and are entitled to access it. With this rule, the Trump Administration has put the government and employers in charge of women’s health care decisions. As a result, tens of millions of women across the country and millions in New York could lose access to affordable birth control.   The Affordable Care Act made preventive services, including contraceptives, available with no copay. Sixty-two million American women, including 3.5 million New Yorkers, are benefiting from these protections today. Yet due to this new rule, a woman’s access to one of the most fundamental health care services will now depend on her employer’s religion and personally held beliefs. That’s not freedom. That’s sexism. That’s placing the employer’s views above a choice that should be made between a woman and her doctor. Free access to birth control supports women’s health. That’s why I strongly oppose this rule and will do everything possible to see it overturned.

Today I joined gun safety advocates to call on GOP Congressional Leaders to publicly reject bills that would weaken gun safety protections.  Congress’s first priority should be to keep people safe, but when it comes to gun violence we are failing miserably. It is time for Republicans in Congress to abandon efforts like the SHARE Act and Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act that would weaken our gun safety laws and put New Yorkers at the mercy of the weakest gun laws in the country. Instead, we need to pass common sense, effective reforms like universal background checks, an assault weapons ban, and stricter gun trafficking laws. These will help save lives, while at the same time respect the Second Amendment. A strong majority of the American people support these reforms; it’s time that a majority in Congress did so as well.  Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America Gays Against Guns New Yorkers Against Gun Violence Manhattan District Attorney's Office Public Advocate Letitia James Scott M. Stringer Gale Brewer Brian Kavanagh Dan Quart
Open enrollment for the Affordable Care Act begins on November 1st. Come hear from experts on how to navigate the system, ask questions, and voice your concerns. Panelists TBD.

If President Donald J. Trump and the Pentagon didn’t coordinate the #TransBan decision, it would represent a huge breakdown in communication. That’s why today, I joined 114 of my colleagues to send a letter to General Mattis, requesting any correspondence on the this horrible policy before it was announced by the President.
Today, I asked Trey Gowdy & Representative Elijah E. Cummings for a hearing on the IRS's contract extension with Equifax after data breach. This decision needs review.

Counting every person in this country every ten years is a Constitutional obligation that dates back to our founding, yet because of chronic underfunding, the 2020 Census is at serious risk of failure.  With just three years to go before the 2020 Census, critical planning, testing and outreach are being cut back due to lack of funds and the Census Bureau is in desperate need of additional funding now to get things back on track. That is why today, I introduced the 2020 American Census Investment Act.   This bill will provide the Census Bureau with the funding it needs to conduct a fair, accurate, and cost effective census. The choice is simple – we can pay now or ask our constituents to pay far more later down the road – or worse, we can own the first ever failure to fulfill our Constitutional duty to deliver a full, fair and complete count of the nation.

The Trump Justice Department’s threat to cut off $4.3 million in federal funding for New York City law enforcement agencies because we are a so-called ‘sanctuary city’ is as outrageous as it is moronic. Cutting off this funding for the nation’s largest city and number one terrorist target will only make it more difficult to keep people safe. New Yorkers will not be intimidated. We will stand for our values and fight this tooth and nail. We are a city of immigrants and proud of it.  That is why I am a cosponsor of H.R. 748, the Safeguarding Sanctuary Cities Act, which would prohibit the administration from withholding federal funds to cities who do not comply with the administrations draconian, heartless immigrant round up. Our Immigrant communities are our partners in keeping communities safe, not bargaining chips for federal law enforcement resources.

Today's terrorist attack was a preplanned barbaric act of violence against innocent civilians that deserves the condemnation of every citizen of every nation. Yet even in the face of such savagery, I know that our city is too strong, too resilient, to let terrorists dictate how we live. We intend to carry on with the same vigor and determination that lights up our city every day, even in the darkest of times.   I am incredibly grateful for the swift response of New York’s finest and our first responders, and for the abundance of caution the NYPD is exhibiting with their stepped-up presence to keep our city feeling safe. I am confident that the NYPD and FBI will conduct a thorough investigation and bring the perpetrator to justice.  Our hearts break today for the families of the eight people killed by this madman and I send my hopes for swift recoveries to all those injured. We will stay New York strong, and get through this together.
NA

The GOP’s tax plan is a complete and total disaster. It would raise taxes on the middle class, double tax New Yorkers, increase the national debt, and lay the ground work for devastating cuts to Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.   Right now, New York is the largest donor state in the nation. In 2015 alone, we sent $48 billion more in taxes to the federal government than we received back. Under this new GOP plan, that inequity will become even worse. That is because the GOP bill eliminates the State and Local Tax (SALT) deduction while also capping property tax deductions.   The SALT deduction is the most widely used benefit in the tax code in New York. If Congress approves this partial elimination of the SALT deduction, it will create tremendous pressure on state and local governments to cut back funding for schools, infrastructure, health, local law enforcement, and first responders. This tax plan penalizes New Yorkers for taking care of our own. That is totally unacceptable.   I will be voting against this harmful GOP tax hike plan and urging my colleagues to do the same. Our country needs and deserves a far better deal that puts middle class families and protects New Yorkers from this outrageous double taxation plan.
NY: it's time to #GetCovered! Open enrollment runs from Nov 1 - Jan 31. You can find a plan that's right for you at nystateofhealth.ny.gov

My heart is broken by this horrific mass shooting at the First Baptist Church in Southerland Springs, TX. I grieve and pray for everyone murdered and injured today.   To violently target so many innocent people in a place where they gather for prayer is inexcusable and inhuman. Unfortunately, this is not the first time we have seen such an atrocity and until this nation decides to enact common-sense gun safety reforms, tragically, it won’t be the last.    No one person should be able to inflict so much pain, and be responsible for so much violence. More than 20 people were murdered today and at least 20 more injured by a man with a gun. Enough is enough. It is far past time for Congress to escape the grip of the NRA and to act to prevent gun violence in this country.

Mass shootings have become way too common in the United States. No industrialized country in the world come us to us in terms of gun violence.   Enough is enough. We need to enact common-sense gun safety reforms to prevent gun violence. That's why I support universal background checks, No Fly No Buy, magazine limits, and new proposals to ban bump stocks. It's also why I have introduced 5 separate gun safety bills to close the gun show background check loophole, allow publicly-funded research into gun violence and how we can prevent it, make gun trafficking a federal offense, require gun owners to own insurance similar to car insurance, and  promote the development of smart gun technology.  You can read more about these efforts on my website.
Even conservative Tax Foundation ‏estimates the #GOPTaxScam will explode the deficit. Share to tell the GOP that’s reckless.
Who are the Americans paying more under the #GOPTaxScam?   Middle-class families, teachers, Americans paying off student loans, small businesses, & homeowners.

This Veterans Day, I honor and thank all of the veterans who have served and sacrificed on our behalf. As the daughter, spouse, and sister of veterans, I know well all that these brave men and women give up in the service of our nation. I am so grateful for the freedoms we enjoy thanks to everyone who serves and has served in our armed forces. We owe veterans a debt of gratitude today and everyday.

Brooklyn came to D.C. last night. It was so good to see so many Brooklyn friends and businesses represented in the halls of Congress.  I'm so honored to represent the people of Brooklyn and was thrilled that my colleagues in Congress got to experience a little taste of what the Borough of Kings has to offer. Thanks to the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce for organizing a terrific showcase of some of Brooklyn's finest. Our nation's capital is the better for it.

I'm glad I was able to join the Confederation of Indian Industry last night and meet leaders of Indian businesses in the U.S. to learn how they are investing in New York City. Our city's diversity -- ethnic, cultural, and economic -- is our strength and is at the heart of what makes New York the greatest city in the world.

I voted no today on the #GOPTaxScam bill becausec this "tax cut" bill is really a tax increase on hard working NYers that will be devastating for the city that I love. House Republicans cheered after they jammed through their tax bill, but for us New Yorkers, there is nothing to cheer about.

Yesterday, the official analysis of the #GOPTaxScam was released, confirming what we've long known: this bill is completely unacceptable. It will hurt everyday Americans & explode the deficit. I'll continue to fight this bill because NY & our country deserve #ABetterDeal.

The Senate Republican tax bill that passed just a few hours ago will raise taxes and health care costs for millions of middle class and low income Americans, while blowing up the national debt. It is no wonder they did this in the middle of the night because it is a shameful, embarrassing travesty of a bill that no one should be proud of. I will be voting NO on this #GOPTaxScam. Our country deserves #ABetterDeal that gives tax relief to working families and small businesses instead of ridiculous giveaways to giant corporations and the fortunate few.

Kansas' failed experiment should be a clear example to the GOP of how not to do tax cuts & shouldnt be repeated. Instead, #GOPTaxScam is cut from the exact same cloth, so we should expect the same disastrous results, only this time on a MUCH bigger scale.

Couldn't have said it any better: The #GOPTaxScam is "an economic dagger aimed at high-tax, high-cost and generally Democratic-leaning areas — most notably New York City and its neighbors." I will keep fighting against the bill and for our city and state.

House & Senate Republicans are now scrambling to agree on a tax bill. But no matter which way you slice it, millions of middle class and low-income Americans will lose out. Our country deserves #ABetterDeal.

The US has the highest rate of gun deaths in the economically developed world & the most guns per capita. Clearly, guns aren't making us safer. Yet, instead of enacting #gunsafety laws, The House GOP is working to weaken gun laws by passing the Conceal Carry Reciprocity Act. Unacceptable.

I am outraged that President Erdogan is using a visit to Greece, intended to strengthen ties between the two countries, to raise the possibility of opening discussions of border issues settled in the 1923 Treaty of Lausanne. Turkey’s suggestion that it has a claim to islands that are part of Greece is outrageous and provocative. I agree with Greece’s President Prokopis Pavlopoulos that the Treaty of Lausanne should be viewed as non-negotiable.

Today I was joined by my colleagues in Congress, law enforcement, and gun safety advocates to take a stand against the terrible #ConcealedCarryReciprocityAct. It is a violation of states' rights and will put New Yorkers at risk.

This morning’s attempted terrorist attack is another somber reminder that New York City, a beacon of freedom, hope, and the American Dream remains the top terrorist target in the country.  I wish the three people injured today a swift and full recovery.  By attacking New York’s subway system, this terrorist was trying to attack our city’s lifeblood and strike fear into the hearts of everyday New Yorkers. But New Yorkers will always persevere in the face adversity. We will never allow terrorists to dictate how we live. Just as we always have, we will stay New York strong and carry on together after this attack.  I am deeply grateful for the tireless work of our first responders and law enforcement agencies for their swift response today and all they do every day to protect our city and remind all New Yorkers, "if you see something, say something."

The 17 women who have accused Donald J. Trump of sexual misconduct must be heard. Proud to join the Democratic Women's Working Group in calling for a full Congressional investigation of these allegations against the President.

I'm proud to join Keith Ellison and my colleagues in opposing any rollbacks to #NetNeutrality. I hope Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai will head our call to protect free speech and our thriving internet economy.

Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai should listen to the American people and #SaveNetNeutrality. #NetNeutrality ensures free speech, equal access, and allows for innovation. It's clear why we shouldn't dismantle it.

No matter the outcome of today's Federal Communications Commission vote, I will continue to do all I can to fight for #NetNeutrality. Chairman Pai's misguided plan threatens free speech, access, and innovation. Unacceptable.
It may be 5 years later, but we will never forget them. #Newtown

A free and open internet safeguards free speech, puts consumers first, and protects small businesses and innovators. But today, the FCC voted to repeal the #netneutrality rules that protect the free and open internet we know today. I’m proud to join my colleagues in this effort to roll back the FCC's harmful decision and am pleased to support U.S. Representative Mike Doyle’s bill to keep our Net Neutrality protections in place.

We need to end the corporate culture of secrecy surrounding sexual harassment settlements and to no longer allow companies to treat Bill O’Reilly-like severances as the cost of doing business. I'm announcing two bills to do just that.
NA

“Potential employees may have no idea about what kind of environment they are about to enter. With total secrecy, companies have absolutely no incentive to focus on preventing sexual misconduct if they know they will never be held accountable.”

I just voted no on #GOPTaxScam because Americans deserve #ABetterDeal than a plan that guts the state and local tax deduction and double-taxes states like NY for taking care of our own, robs the middle class to provide tax breaks for big business, & rips away #healthcare from millions of Americans. It will also add more than $1 trillion to the national debt. It is shameful that the GOP would pass a bill as harmful as this.

Today, the House voted – for the third and final time – on the deeply flawed and misguided Republican tax bill. In this case, the third time was definitely not the charm. This bill is not reform, it is a scam that is particularly cruel to New York – which is why I voted no all three times.  NPR published this great explainer of the differences between current law and what the GOP tax bill will enact. I hope you find it useful.

Firing Special Counsel Mueller would be an outrageous abuse of executive power. I’m proud to stand with 171 other Democratic members of the House in support of allowing Special Counsel Mueller to finish his investigation without interference or political pressure.
Combating sexual harassment in the workplace means holding companies accountable for their employees' actions. My two new bills will help do that.

Happy New Year! Wishing you all a great year ahead in 2018.

I voted no on the spending bill because it fails to address the huge list of urgent, overdue priorities facing our country. This empty, short-term Republican spending package leaves out any relief for DREAMers, underfunds veterans’ services and efforts to combat opioid abuse, and gives the Children’s Health Insurance Program just three more months of life instead of the long-term security our kids deserve.   I do not believe in shutting down our government but I cannot support another short-term funding patch that is nothing more than kicking the can down the road when we should be doing our jobs now. Working families, veterans, children, and the countless communities across our nation who are fighting the opioid epidemic deserve #ABetterDeal.
